Um es direkt vorher klarzustellen: Ich hab noch keinen Bioshock Teil gespielt, das war der allererste und ich hab ihn mir ehrlich gesagt auch nur zugelegt, weil ich Reviews und Empfehlungen des Todes überall gelesen habe (das natürlich im Positiven gesehen). Als es dann im Angebot war, schlug ich zu und hab es meiner Bibliothek hinzugefügt, jedoch eine lange Zeit nicht angerührt weil ich zu Faul war.

Doch heute der große Tag, andem ich es um 09:00 Uhr frühs gestartet habe und bis knapp 20 Uhr abends durchgespielt habe. Und es gibt fast garkein Spiel, was derartiges bei mir geschafft hat.

Die Story ist richtig krass gut, die Charaktere ebenfalls und die Grafik ist auch wunderschön anzusehen. Natürlich gibt es grafisch gesehen bessere Spiele, aber der Hauptgrund ist höchstwahrscheinlich die Story, warum es mich so gegriffen hat. 
Anfangs dachte ich auch, das Spiel wäre extremst schwer, und man würde an jeder Ecke und Kante sterben, doch so war es keineswegs. Die einzigen Tode waren dumme fails, weil man den Enterhaken nicht richtig eingesetzt hat. Aber die Gegner Fights waren genau richtig - nich zu schwer, nicht zu leicht. Munition an manchen Stellen aweng knapp, aber man weiß sich schon zu helfen - Elizabeth hilft einen des ein oder andere mal :p

Wie ein Puzzle fügt sich alles zusammen, und am Ende dann die große Aufklärung (welche ich natürlich nicht verraten werde). Gefühlsgeladenes Ende und extremst gut dargestellt.

Auch wenn man (so wie ich eigentlich) nichts mit Bioshock am Hut hat (und ich entschuldige mich bei eingefleischten Fans der Bioshock-Reihe), so kann man definitiv diesen Teil spielen - die Story machts möglich (zumindest aus meiner Perspektive).

9/10 Punkten. Muss ich mehr sagen? Kauft es euch einfach und lasst euch selbst überwältigen und macht euch ein Bild aus der Story.

One word to describe this game: AMAZEBALLS. I thought BioShock 2 blew BioShock out of the water, but this game is REALLY fun and challenging.

If you've played the previous two games, you will enjoy this one immensely. It's quite different, though in that it not only takes place in a different setting, but there's TWO playable characters. You are Booker (voiced by the talented Troy Baker, famous for his lead role as Joel from The Last of Us), tasked with finding the young woman named Elizabeth, who teams up with you to escape Columbia, a massive utopia floating in the sky. You fight through mobs of religious zealots who seceded from the USA, and cultists who worship John Wilkes Booth, with Elizabeth's help and guidance from two twins who are neither here nor there. Confused yet? It gets better.

Plasmids have been replaced with Vigors, which are fueled not by EVE but by salts instead. One of my favorite Vigors can "soak up" small projectiles, then explode outward, sending ammo back at your enemies (this REALLY comes in handy later in the game). The weapons and Vigors are much different from the previous two games, too. And though you will collect more firearms than before, you can only equip a few at a time, which adds an element of strategy to combat situations. The Skyhook is an awesome addition, as well. What is it? Well, it is what it sounds like: a magnetic hook that allows you to grab onto rails throughout the city of Columbia and zip around. You can also drop on unsuspecting idiots for an instant kill (same with melee attacks). It's really amusing and fun pulling those off.

You may ask, "Do I have to play the prequels first?" No, you don't, actually, but I HIGHLY recommend it. The endings of those two games are great, especially BioShock 2 (and its DLC, Minerva's Den). However, the ending to this one takes the cake. Talk about a mindfuck! So I definitely recommend this game, hell, ALL of them.

Booker DeWitt es un ex soldado que trabaja como investigador privado en la Nueva York de principios del siglo XX. Abrumado por las deudas, acepta un encargo de rescatar a una chica encerrada en una magnífica ciudad flotante llamada Columbia, y que parece dirigida por un fanático religioso con poderes proféticos. Lo que empieza como una simple misión de rescate se convierte en una odisea plagada de sangre, revolución y misteriosos fenómenos, además de secretos enterrados en las mentes tanto de Booker como de la peculiar chica a la que debe sacar de Columbia.

BioShock Infinite da un salto magistral con respecto a sus predecesores. Sin tener conexión argumental con ellos, conserva su esencia (shooter ágil, poderes, mucha acción, filosofías conflictivas y escenarios espectaculares) y la lleva más allá. La jugabilidad mejora considerablemente, hay una gran variedad de armas y poderes, muchas posibilidades de interactuar con el escenario para facilitar las luchas, y Columbia y su entorno es simplemente increíble, toda una obra de arte. La trama es compleja e interesante, y los personajes bastante más desarrollados y redondos que los de las anteriores entregas (especialmente Elizabeth). Con una duración de unas 20 horas, Bioshock Infinite garantiza mucha diversión a golpe de pistola y vigorizador (plásmidos).

Como defectos destacaría dos cosas. Primero, los enemigos resultan bastante repetitivos. Solo hay hordas de tiradores, que de vez en cuando llevan armas pesadas, y cuatro tipos distintos de enemigos de élite, lo que hace bastante sencillo aprender a manejarse en combate y resolverlo sin complicaciones. Por un lado eso te da mayor margen para probar nuevos combos de armas y vigorizadores, pero a cambio acaba haciendo el combate repetitivo y poco desafiante. El segundo defecto es lo desaprovechado que está el personaje de Elizabeth. A pesar de ser una chica inteligente, con recursos y un caracter y personalidad fuertes, la mayor parte del tiempo está relegada a un segundo plano, yendo a donde Booker la lleve y proporcionando una ayuda superficial y poco relevante, lo que hace que parezca la típica damisela en apuros, un rol que no le hace justicia en absoluto. Por suerte, esto queda subsanado en el DLC "Burial at Sea", donde ella pasa a tener una imagen y caracter más maduros y un papel mucho más relevante.

Disclaimer: I never played the first two Bioshock games and as such reviewed the game on its own merit and not how good it is for a Bioshock game.

Bioshock Infinite is the last game Irrational studios made. It is set in the wonderfully created Columbia. Columbia is a beautiful sight to behold (On the outside). The graphics are simply amazing, with big open levels and actual variety in the environments (Something that some games set on a whole planet fails to do). You play as Booker DeWitt, a man sent to "Find the girl" so that his employers can "wipe away the debt". As the story continous the story is filled in. Booker eventual finds the girl. Her name is Elizabeth. Never befaore did I like a companion in a game as much as this one. She is a joy to be around. Gameplay wise she makes a huge difference. She has handy and unique abilities that helps Booker during battles. Between battles she follows you and looks around as she goes, often times finding ammo or money. As a charater she is amazing. She has this child like wonder of the world when she is first found, but that slowly dims as she (along with the player) are introduced to the real columbia. The real columbia is a disgusting place. There's violence, racism, corruption and much more just beneath that shiny exterrior. I could go on and on about this game, but instead I`ll just tell you to buy this game. Its simply amazing.

Premetto di non aver ancora giocato ai precedenti episodi della serie, ma visto il risultato ottenuto con questo capitolo, sicuramente un pensiero ce lo farò.
Quindi possiamo affermare che da neofita mi sono avvicinato a questo titolo.
Credo che quando si va a recensire qualsiasi cosa sia impossibile non inserire un'interpretazione soggettiva, quindi non ho la presunzione di considerare queste parole come una verità assoluta, ne tanto meno una guida all'acquisto da seguire come vangelo, ma piuttosto come una sorta di chiacchierata, fatta con un amico che ha appena scoperto quest'opera.
Avendo sempre apprezzato le climax, partirò col parlare dei lati più deboli di questo prodotto per poi addolcire i toni su quelli che vorrei (e sottolineo il vorrei) fossero degli standard per tutti i videogiochi.
Il gameplay, da appassionato della serie Souls, e da non feticista degli FPS, l'ho trovato sicuramente interessante, ma mal sviluppato.
Il numero di armi è appropriato (non eccessivo a mio parere, per evitare sia una realizzazione mediocre sia un eccessiva dispersione da parte dell'utente), ed esse sono sufficientemente caratterizzate e variegate.
L'osticità quindi non l'attribuisco alle bocche da fuoco, ma piuttosto ad un sistema di controllo del combattimento a volte infelice, che soprattutto a distanza ravvicinata risulta confuso da un sovrapporsi di pop-up a schermo (che sono sì un intuitivo aiuto per monitorare la condizione del personaggio, ma finiscono col rimuovere visibilità e "pasticciare" la visuale).
Inoltre, non avrei sgradito la possibilità di lockare i nemici, almeno per quanto concerne il combattimento "all'arma bianca" con l'uso dello sky-hook, che joypad alla mano risulta a volte poco controllabile.
Quindi dopo aver abbandonato il sistema di shoting, che reputo nella media, da 77, passiamo alla realizzazione tecnica del titolo.
Quest'ultima risulta molto più che buona sotto quasi ogni aspetto, fatta eccezione per qualche texture a mio parere un po' trascurata.
Il gioco risulta fluido e a 60 fps (tenore che è risultato pressoché granitico per tutta la mia esperienza) lo ritengo perfettamente godibile.
Quindi se il lato tecnico merita un buon 87, in relazione anche all'anno di sviluppo, quello che assume secondo me un valore fuori scala è il senso artistico del videogioco.
Lo studio fatto nella creazione dell'ambientazione è eccezionale, con un attenzione ai dettagli riscontrabile in ogni singola parte di Columbia; sono infatti stupefacenti le architetture, il comportamento degli npc, i manifesti, i voxafoni, e tutti gli elementi di scena che riescono ad immergere l'utente in un mondo vivo e pulsante.
Ogni elemento è infatti coerente con la storia della città fantascientifica e risulta una magnifica perla anche se estratta dal contesto quasi fiabesco.
Ultima, e più importante, è la storia, che risulta il fiore all'occhiello di quest'opera.
Studiata anch'essa nei minimi dettagli, risulta avvincente, mai banale, ricca di risvolti intelligenti e spesso inaspettati.
Il contesto creato aiuta ad immergersi nel clima classico di un totalitarismo Orwelliano, passatemi il termine, arricchito da una componente religiosa quasi fanatica, che risulta reale e palpabile, e che traspare dalla voce sia dei personaggi sia da quella di Columbia stessa.
I personaggi principali sono ben realizzati e caratterizzati, ognuno di essi presenta una personalità ben definita e coerente.
Essi vanno ad animare un contesto costruito a pennello e sanno più volte regalare spunti di riflessione che vanno oltre al classico videogioco.
Detto questo anche il doppiaggio italiano, di buona fattura, aiuta a non disperdere eccessivamente l'attenzione dell'utente nell'opera di tradurre o leggere i dialoghi, che in un videogioco così complesso avrebbero potuto tediare il giocatore.
Il finale, a mio parere epifania e allegoria dell'opera stessa, chiude ed impacchetta uno dei ricordi più belli della mia esperienza da videogiocatore, e ancora una volta dà credito all'idea che i videogiochi siano realmente l'ottava arte.
In conclusione, quello che vi ho raccontato in "poche parole" è uno dei capolavori del media, e credo che meriti almeno una possibilità per stupire ed affascinare ognuno degli appassionati, anche solo per il gusto di assaporare una città immaginaria così vera...

One of the best games I've ever played. I was already a huge fan of Bioshock: the original was (and still is) one of my favourite games of all time. I skipped the first sequel because it just seemed like more of the same, but I came back to the franchise with Infinite, and boy, did I make the right choice. 

Visually Bioshock Infinite is arresting. I'm not talking about the graphics from a technical standpoint (they are fine, I'm not qualified to say more than that), but I'm referring to the beautiful design and the virtual cinematography. Visually Bioshock Infinite stands with the great, and offers an original vision of an original world.

The gameplay is good, precise, fast and fun. It's intuitive but occasionally demanding. It gets you to the end without boring you and it often challenges you in a non-obvious way (especially when Elizabeth and her powers are involved). 

But gameplay is not the point of the game. Narrative is. Kevin Levine simply wrote one of the most engrossing, surprising and thoughtful pieces of entartainment of the last decade.
His writing is especially amplified by the fact that the player goes through the story with a first person perspective, controlling the main charachter and making choices. This might seem obvious (it is a videogame afterall) but I think it's worth noting, because there are not many artists out there that make full use of the inherent features of the videogame media.
I don't want to give away anything of the plot, but let's just say that the level of identification and the way the narrative affect the player in Bioshock Infinite would not be possible anywhere else, not in a movie, nor a novel.

In conclusion, Bioshock Infinite is a masterpiece. It's one of those (very rare) games that transcend the genre to give the players a complete experience that can keep them entertained, but also intellectually involved over the course of its 12 amazing hours (your mileage may vary).

Der Grafikstil passt sehr gut zum Setting, der Soundtrack ist 1A (vor allem die Abwandlungen von 'Will The Circle Be Unbroken') und die Story... nun ja, so ziemlich die komplexeste die ich bisher in einem Spiel erlebt habe. Quantenphysik, Parallelwelten, etc., mehr will ich hier auch nicht sagen, sonst würde ich spoilern.
Die Immersion ist hervorragend, man fühlt sich tatsächlich wie in den fanatisch-patriotistischen USA des frühen 20. Jahrhunderts, in denen die Gründerväter als Götter verehrt werden. Allein in der Kirche, in der man sich direkt nach dem Aufstieg nach Columbia befindet, habe ich eine knappe halbe Stunde verbracht um die Atmosphäre zu genießen und nach Secrets zu suchen, so sehr hat mich das Spiel bereits kurz nach Anfang mitgerissen.
Hierbei handelt sich um einen Shooter, auf dessen Atmosphäre man sich komplett einlassen muss, um ihn voll auskosten zu können. Klar, man kann sich auch hirnlos bis zum Ende durchballern wie in CoD oder Battlefield, aber dazu ist BioShock nicht gemacht und das wird es auch niemals sein. Und das ist, meiner Meinung nach, auch sehr gut so.
Bioshock of Duty: Pretentious Borefare

Thematically, Bioshock Infinate has a rather distinctive victorian era asthetic, blending in some interesting fantasy elements (like the city in the sky) and some crazy steam punk contraptions. Not necessarily totally unique elements but together I found the concept was quite novel and that this theming aspect was one of the game's strongest suits.  

The amount of attention to detail and polish in the world is second to none and it was clearly created with a lot of care and attention by the devs. The game also ran very smoothly on my PC, and I was able to experience 100 FPS throughout the entire game.

As an FPS, the shooting mechanics felt solid and satisfying with enough variety in weapons, portals and 'Vigor' (like magic spells) to keep the combat relatively fresh throughout my 11 hour playthrough. The sound and weight of the weapons also felt accurate to how they would be. However, whilst this aspect of the game was good, I would refrain from saying it was amazing. I found the 2 weapon cap a little annoying and I would frequenly have no idea which direction/s I was taking damage from or exactly what I was supposed to target, especially towards the end of the game when things get a bit more hectic.

Now for the more divisive comment, regarding the story. I had been told how this game would blow your mind for being such a clever and incisive story, so maybe I had overhyped it in my mind and I will keep this review spolier free, but I can say that whilst it was relativly compelling and kept my interest through until the end, I was not blown away by it by any means. I was able to predict a lot of the ending a few hours earlier, so during the last 30 minutes I was waiting for the big twist but I was always able to stay a couple minutes in front of the unfolding story in my head, so never really experienced that major "shock" everyone was talking about. There were also some instances I thought were a little contrived and psudo-philosophical at the end. Basically, for any sci-fi or fantasy nerd, the story is not as unique as it purports to be, but credit still has to be given because it was still presented in a clean and coherent fashion.

Personal opinion, don't hate: Decent FPS, Decent Story, Strong theme and asthetic. 7/10
